description: From Middle English durren, from Old English durran, from Proto-West Germanic *durʀan, from Proto-Germanic *durzaną (“to dare”), from Proto-Indo-European *dʰedʰórse (“to dare”), reduplicated stative of the root *dʰers- (“to be bold, to dare”), an *-s- extension of *dʰer- (“to hold, support”).

entries.meaning: The quality of daring; venturesomeness; boldness.
(games) In the game truth or dare, the choice to perform a dare set by the other players.
examples: When asked truth or dare, she picked dare.

verbs.description: dare (third-person singular simple present dare or dares or (archaic) dast, present participle daring, simple past and past participle dared or (archaic) durst)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have enough courage (to do something).
examples: I wouldn't dare (to) argue with my boss.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To defy or challenge (someone to do something)
examples: I dare you to kiss that girl.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To have enough courage to meet or do something, go somewhere, etc.; to face up to
examples: Will you dare death to reach your goal?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To catch (larks) by producing terror through the use of mirrors, scarlet cloth, a hawk, etc., so that they lie still till a net is thrown over them.

description: From Middle English, from Old English darian.

verbs.description: dare (third-person singular simple present dares, present participle daring, simple past and past participle dared)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To stare stupidly or vacantly; to gaze as though amazed or terrified. [16thc.]
(obsolete) To lie or crouch down in fear. [16thc.]
